@ijuma @hachikuji Yes, I have just realized the same. My idea for now would be to move those sanity checks to the `DefaultRecordBatch` somewhere, to validate that everything makes sense, because if the number of records matches the expected one, and we have all headers then the rest of the checks will be done on them by the `validateMessagesAndAssignOffsets`.
WDYT?

Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

Rather than throw a different exception with the original exception as cause, making it harder to handle the exception in the client, it may be better to add a new suppressed exception to the request exception for providing the caller stack trace using `Throwable#addSuppressed`.

I agree with @guozhangwang regarding whether topic validation should exist in ProducerRecord. It sort of seems putting a topic validation check in the ProducerRecord is excessive, especially given that we're moving away from auto topic creation.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/4924/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

TLDR; surprisingly it looks like close doesn't call flush,  adding `flushInternal` call to `RocksDBStore# close()`.

close sequence:
      `RocksDB.close()` -> 
     `disposeInternal()`  ->
      `disposeInteral(long nativeHandle)` 

which ultimately makes its way to  `rocksjni.cc` line 1492 `Java_org_rocksdb_RocksDB_disposeInternal` and  deletes the underlying object pointer.

EDIT: Nevermind, looks like the destructor is called when deleting underlying object pointer, but I think we should still leave in the flush call on close.
@vahidhashemian You could update one of the existing tests that raises this exception to check the suppressed exception.
@hachikuji Can you take a look please? Thank you...

@reftel @rajinisivaram The PR was just updated based on the recent feedback.

Those tests passed for the first time after applying these changes.

Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

@junrao @ijuma Thank you for the review. I have responded to the comments and added a test to ensure that client host address is not validated by the server even if `SSLParameters#setEndpointIdentificationAlgorithm("HTTPS")` is set. If Java supports client validation in the future, the unit test would fail and we can update the code to handle this case.

@mjsax Does the recent update solve the limitation about tests?

@gosubpl Yes, that makes sense to me. When iterating the batch, we can keep track of the number of records and raise an error if we reach the end earlier than expected or if the expected count is reached and there are still remaining bytes. The header check can do something similar in `DefaultRecord`.

@mihbor, thanks for this and other PRs. Keep in mind that there is overhead for a committer to review and merge each PR. So, one PR with a few documentation improvements is better than 5 small documentation PRs where some of the PRs change a single line.

```text
	at org.junit.Assert.assertTrue(Assert.java:41)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.producer.internals.BufferPoolTest.testBlockTimeout(BufferPoolTest.java:191)
```
